GENERAL OFFICE
Personal and

ALAMEDA -
October 7, 1937
DISTRICT TRAFFIC OFFICE
MANILA HOTEL
Dear Mr. Morgan
and
I have just returned from Hongkong, am taking this
only opportunity to rush off
a short letter to you via Clipper
leaving
tonight in order to
give you some of the bachground
which
may assist you in understanding
cabled recommendations which otherwise
might be wholly non-understandable.
We have been diligently searching for some method
which offers
some hope of
salvage for PAA in our Chinese effort. Such
an operation must have the advantage of not weakening our
present sit-
uation
respecting possible
claims against the
Government of Chinaif
there
be any such entity when
the war is over) and yet represent what the
Chinese may call a constructive program.
In Hongkong I met Bond, Lum and P.Y.Wong:
The Managing
Director ( Lum) has clearly been told to get our cooperation for he
fairly
crawled
and
presented a truly pathetic spectacle in face of his former
swash buckling attitude,
He said quite
simply " We must have
the Americans
back"â€¢
The Chinese have cracked up
in terrible condition,
their own pilots are
ste are lares, to tient as setting
to fly it and
public is losing confidence.
Chinese pilot
their best one (Donald
Wong) has lost so much confidence and was so badly
treated by his own
people that he went AWOL and is now
on his way to
the U,s.
Other Chinese
pilots are getting fedup with
Chinese management,
The Company needs
direction,
spare
parts,
and most of all
they need
the prestige which
unappreciated o1 a
Connection with American
operating
personnel.
They
are
ready
tomake any reasonable
compromise
to
secure
our
cooperation.
Under
the circumstances Bond and
I
feel that we
be
able
get
definite
on the liability of
the Government
to the
American
shareholders
and at the
same
time set the stage for a
back in the
event
that
least a part
the
Chinese
should come out of the present
struggle with at
of
their country left andready for reconstruction.

of renewing
our
to
